definitions: shoot at someone from a concealed position at long distance
make unpleasant critical remarks about someone in an indirect way
examples: The soldier sniped at enemy troops from the rooftop
Hunters would snipe birds from behind thick bushes
Critics continued to snipe at the mayor's new policies
Stop sniping at each other and work together peacefully

definitions: secretly tell someone in authority about something bad that someone has done
take something of little value without permission from its owner
examples: Tommy snitched on his classmates to the teacher
Nobody likes people who snitch to the boss
Someone snitched my favorite pen from my desk drawer
Kids would snitch candy from the store when nobody watched

definitions: play a game on a table with colored balls and long sticks
trick someone into a difficult position or prevent them from doing something
examples: They snookered for hours at the local billiards club
My grandfather taught me how to snooker when I was young
The lawyer snookered the witness with clever questioning tactics
Don't let them snooker you into signing that contract

definitions: secretly look around in someone's private things to find out information
examples: She caught her roommate snooping through her personal diary
The detective snooped around the suspect's apartment for clues
Neighbors would snoop behind curtains to watch our activities
Stop snooping in my business and mind your own affairs

definitions: swim underwater using a tube to breathe air from above the surface
examples: We snorkeled in the crystal clear waters near the reef
Children love to snorkel and explore the shallow ocean floor
Tourists snorkel every morning to see tropical fish up close
She learned to snorkel during her vacation in Hawaii

definitions: make and throw balls of snow at someone or something for fun
grow quickly in size or importance like a rolling snowball getting bigger
examples: The children snowballed each other during the winter break
We used to snowball passing cars when we were kids
The small protest snowballed into a nationwide movement overnight
Her debt problems snowballed when she lost her job suddenly

definitions: ride down snowy slopes on a single board attached to both feet
examples: She snowboards every weekend at the mountain resort nearby
Teenagers love to snowboard and perform tricks in terrain parks
He learned to snowboard last winter and now loves it
Professional athletes snowboard down dangerous mountain slopes for competitions

definitions: deliberately ignore someone in a rude way to show you don't like them
examples: She snubbed her ex-boyfriend at the party last night
The celebrity snubbed reporters waiting outside the restaurant entrance
Don't snub your colleagues just because you got promoted
He felt hurt when old friends snubbed him in public

definitions: put out a candle or flame by pinching or covering it
breathe in powdered tobacco or other substance through the nose
examples: She snuffed the candle before leaving the room for safety
The wind snuffed out our campfire during the storm
In old times people would snuff tobacco as a habit
Some cultures still snuff ceremonial powders during religious rituals

definitions: put something in liquid for a long time to make it completely wet
take in liquid through a surface gradually over time
examples: Soak the beans overnight before cooking them tomorrow morning
She soaked her tired feet in warm salt water
The sponge will soak up all the spilled milk quickly
Heavy rain soaked through my jacket within minutes

definitions: fly high in the air with little effort using air currents
rise very quickly to a high level or amount
examples: Eagles soar above the mountain peaks searching for prey
The glider soared gracefully through the clear blue sky
House prices soared after the new subway station opened
Her spirits soared when she heard the good news

definitions: cry in a noisy way with short breaths because of strong emotion
examples: The child sobbed loudly after falling off her bicycle
She sobbed with relief when she found her lost dog
He sobbed uncontrollably at his best friend's funeral service
Don't sob over spilled milk; accidents happen to everyone

definitions: become less affected by alcohol or make someone become less drunk
examples: The cold shower helped sober him up before work
Strong coffee won't actually sober you up despite popular belief
She needed to sober up before driving home from the party
Fresh air and time will sober even the drunkest person

definitions: spend time with other people for pleasure in friendly activities or conversation
examples: University helps students socialise and make lifelong friends together
She doesn't socialise much since moving to the new city
Dogs need to socialise with other dogs from young age
The company organises events to help employees socialise after work

definitions: participate in social activities and spend time with other people for enjoyment
examples: Children learn to socialize through playing games with peers
It's important to socialize regularly for good mental health
The new student struggled to socialize in the unfamiliar environment
We socialize with neighbors at the community barbecue every summer

definitions: make something less hard or firm than it was before
become less severe harsh or strict in manner or attitude
examples: Butter will soften quickly if left at room temperature
Use fabric softener to soften rough towels after washing
His expression softened when he saw his daughter's tears
The teacher softened her tone with the frightened student

definitions: stay somewhere temporarily as a visitor or guest during travels
examples: The artist sojourned in Paris to study French painting techniques
We sojourned at a mountain cabin during our hiking trip
Many writers sojourn in quiet places to finish their novels
The family sojourned with relatives while their house was renovated

definitions: give comfort or consolation to someone in a time of distress or sadness
examples: Music solaced her during the difficult divorce proceedings
Friends tried to solace him after his mother passed away
She solaced herself with chocolate after the bad news
Nature walks solace many people dealing with stress and anxiety

definitions: join pieces of metal together using melted metal alloy as adhesive
examples: The technician soldered the broken wire back to the circuit
You need steady hands to solder tiny electronic components
He learned to solder copper pipes during plumbing apprenticeship
Jewelers solder precious metals to create beautiful rings

definitions: ask for something such as money help or information from people
approach someone and offer to provide services especially of questionable nature
examples: Charities solicit donations during the holiday season every year
The company solicited feedback from customers about new products
Street vendors solicit tourists near popular attractions all day
It's illegal to solicit in this neighborhood after dark

definitions: change from liquid to solid state or make something become solid
make something such as an idea or relationship stronger and more definite
examples: The melted chocolate will solidify in the refrigerator overnight
Lava solidifies into rock when it cools down completely
The agreement solidified their business partnership for years ahead
Recent events solidified her decision to change careers

definitions: roll the body over forward or backward in a complete circle
examples: The gymnast somersaulted perfectly across the mat three times
Children love to somersault on soft grass during playtime
The diver somersaulted twice before entering the water cleanly
Can you still somersault like when you were a kid

definitions: make someone feel calm and less anxious upset or angry
make pain or discomfort less severe with gentle treatment
examples: The mother soothed her crying baby with a lullaby
Soft music soothes my nerves after a stressful day
This cream will soothe your sunburned skin within minutes
Warm tea with honey soothes a scratchy sore throat

definitions: use something absorbent to soak up liquid especially with bread
examples: He sopped up the gravy with a piece of fresh bread
Use paper towels to sop the spilled juice quickly
She sopped her bread in the delicious soup broth
The mop will sop up water from the flooded basement

definitions: feel or express deep distress and sadness about something
examples: She sorrowed over the loss of her childhood home
The whole nation sorrowed when the beloved leader died
Parents sorrow when their children move far away permanently
He sorrowed for months after his dog passed away

definitions: become unfriendly or unpleasant in mood attitude or relationship
become bad-tasting or spoiled especially milk or other food
examples: Their friendship soured after the business deal went wrong
The conversation soured when politics came up at dinner
Milk will sour quickly if left out of the refrigerator
The cream soured before we could use it for cooking

definitions: plant seeds in the ground so that plants will grow
cause something to begin or develop that will have consequences later
examples: Farmers sow wheat seeds in early spring for harvest
She sowed wildflower seeds throughout her entire garden
His careless words sowed doubt in everyone's minds about the plan
The scandal sowed division within the political party

definitions: move around outside a spacecraft while in space wearing a special suit
examples: Astronauts spacewalk to repair equipment on the space station
She trained for years before her first spacewalk mission
The crew will spacewalk tomorrow to install new solar panels
Spacewalking requires careful preparation and safety protocols

definitions: dig earth or move material using a digging tool with flat blade
examples: He spaded the garden bed before planting spring vegetables
Workers spaded tons of dirt to create the new pathway
She spaded compost into the soil to enrich it naturally
Gardeners spade their plots every year before planting season

definitions: send the same message to large numbers of people on the internet
examples: Hackers spam millions of email addresses with fake offers daily
Don't spam the forum with your advertisements please
Companies that spam customers often lose their reputation quickly
My inbox gets spammed with dozens of junk emails

definitions: extend from one side to another across an area or distance
continue to exist or happen over a particular period of time
examples: The bridge spans the river connecting both sides of town
Her arms couldn't span the width of the ancient tree
His career spanned five decades in the film industry
The Roman Empire spanned several centuries of human history

definitions: practice boxing or fighting moves with someone for training
argue with someone in a friendly way using clever remarks
examples: Boxers spar regularly to prepare for important championship matches
The fighters sparred for hours perfecting their technique
The siblings constantly spar about politics at family dinners
Coworkers spar good-naturedly during lunch break conversations

definitions: shine brightly with many small flashes of reflected light
examples: Diamonds sparkle beautifully under the jewelry store lights
Fresh snow sparkles in the bright morning sunshine
Her eyes sparkled with excitement about the surprise party
The ocean sparkled like scattered jewels on sunny days

definitions: have a brief quarrel or disagreement about something unimportant
examples: The couple spatted over which movie to watch tonight
Neighbors spatted about the property line between their yards
Don't spat with your sister over such silly things
They spatted constantly but always made up quickly

definitions: produce or deposit eggs especially as fish or frogs do
cause something to happen or be created as a result
examples: Salmon spawn upstream in the rivers where they were born
Frogs spawn thousands of eggs in ponds each spring
The successful movie spawned several sequels and merchandise lines
One small incident spawned a revolution that changed everything

definitions: pierce or strike something with a pointed weapon or sharp object
examples: Ancient hunters would spear fish in shallow river waters
He speared the piece of meat with his fork
The player speared the ball with incredible accuracy and speed
Divers spear fish for food in tropical waters

definitions: lead an attack or an important activity or movement
examples: She spearheaded the campaign to save the local library
The general spearheaded the assault on enemy positions
Environmental groups spearhead efforts to reduce plastic waste globally
Young activists spearhead social movements through online platforms

definitions: concentrate on and become expert in a particular area of activity
examples: Doctors often specialise in specific types of medical treatment
The restaurant specialises in authentic Italian seafood dishes
She decided to specialise in pediatric nursing after graduation
Our firm specialises in environmental law and regulations

definitions: mark something with many small spots or pieces of something
examples: Paint specked her clothes after the art class project
Mud specked the car windows during the rainy drive
Stars speck the night sky like diamonds on black velvet
Freckles specked her nose and cheeks in summer

definitions: mark or cover something with many small spots or patches of color
examples: Sunlight speckled the forest floor through gaps in leaves
Age had speckled the old painting with brown spots
The artist speckled the canvas with dots of bright paint
Rain speckled the windshield as we drove through storms

definitions: form opinions or theories about something without having definite knowledge
invest money in stocks or property hoping to make profit from changes
examples: Scientists speculate about life on other planets beyond Earth
Reporters speculated wildly about the celebrity's sudden disappearance
Investors speculate on cryptocurrency hoping for massive returns
Don't speculate with money you cannot afford to lose

definitions: add herbs or spices to food to give it more flavor
add excitement or interest to something that seems boring
examples: She spiced the curry with fresh ginger and hot peppers
Always spice your food while cooking not after serving
Travel stories spiced up the dinner conversation considerably
He spiced his presentation with humor to engage students

definitions: speak at length about something especially to persuade or sell
examples: The salesman spieled about the car's features for twenty minutes
Don't let him spiel; we need quick answers today
She spieled enthusiastically about her new business venture idea
Tour guides spiel the same historical facts every single day

definitions: increase suddenly and sharply to a much higher level
add alcohol or drugs to someone's drink without their knowledge
examples: Gas prices spiked during the holiday travel season again
Her blood pressure spiked when she heard the news
Someone spiked the punch at the high school dance
Never leave drinks unattended; someone might spike them

definitions: move in a continuous curve that winds around a central point
continuously become worse in a way that is difficult to control
examples: The eagle spiraled upward on warm air currents
Smoke spiraled from the chimney into the cold air
The economy spiraled into recession after the market crash
Her debt spiraled out of control within just six months

definitions: cause liquid to scatter in drops by hitting or disturbing it
make something or someone wet with scattered drops of liquid
examples: Children love to splash in puddles after rain storms
The whale splashed dramatically as it dove back underwater
Be careful not to splash paint on the new carpet
Passing cars splashed pedestrians with muddy water

definitions: scatter or splash liquid or soft substance in messy drops
examples: Grease splattered everywhere when she cooked bacon too fast
Rain splattered against the window during the fierce storm
The artist splattered paint across the canvas creating abstract art
Mud splattered on their clothes during the obstacle race

definitions: join two pieces of rope film or other material together at the ends
examples: Sailors know how to splice ropes for maximum strength
The editor spliced different scenes together creating seamless transitions
Engineers spliced fiber optic cables to restore internet service
Film makers used to splice movie reels by hand

definitions: support a broken bone with a rigid device to keep it still
examples: The paramedic splinted his broken arm before hospital transport
Veterinarians splint animal fractures just like human doctors
You should splint the injury to prevent further damage
They splinted her finger using popsicle sticks and tape

definitions: break into small thin sharp pieces of wood or similar material
examples: The old wooden fence splintered when hit by the truck
Dry wood splinters easily when you try to nail it
The glass splintered into thousands of tiny dangerous pieces
The political party splintered into several competing factions
